conclusion: Consider the concept of total internal reflection (TIR).
Light enters the sphere at point A with an incident angle i.
Light travels from air (less dense) into the sphere (denser).
According to Snell's Law, n1 sin(i) = n2 sin(r).
If i increases, refracted angle r will also increase.
Critical angle ic is defined by ic = sin^(-1)(n1/n2).
For TIR, light must travel from denser to less dense medium.
Angle of incidence inside the sphere must be greater than ic for TIR.
Light travels through the sphere, reaching point B.
Evaluate exit angle at point B to see if it exceeds ic.
If angle at point B is greater than ic, TIR will occur.
Given large incident angle i, refracted angle r will be large.
If r exceeds ic at point B, total internal reflection will occur.
If incident angle i is large enough, light will be totally internally reflected.
